text.p: Lithuanian newspapers carried the following reports in their Thursday editions. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- The leader of Homeland Union (Conservatives) Vytautas Landsbergis denies rumors that if the conservatives and Christian Democrats win two-thirds of seats in parliament they will amend the constitution and the president will be elected by parliament and not by the direct vote.
- Lithuanian government appealed to President Algirdas Brazauskas to recall Lithuanian ambassador in Ukraine, Romualdas Ramoska, who is suspected of document forgery.
- Lithuanian Prime Minister Mindaugas Stankevicius, 61, has health problems with high blood presure and will go to hospital for health checks.

- President of Lithuanian Confederation of Industrialists, Bronislovas Lubys, supports the idea to abolish the currency board. Lubys says high currency reserves permit the national unit, litas, to be unpegged from the dollar which will stimulate the growth of the Lithuanian economy.
- Homeland Union leader Vytautas Landsbergis, celebrating the victory of his party in parliamentary election, did not deny the possibility that he might stand for presidency next year.
- Defeated during parliament elections, Lithuanian Democratic Labour Party fears radicalism in the newly elected parliament.
